levels.label: entry
levels.description: Writing the correct grapheme for each phoneme in simple CVC words using phoneme frames.
levels.example_task: Say the word 'pen'. Write one letter in each box for each sound you hear.
levels.example_response: Child writes p-e-n in three boxes.
common_errors: Writing only the first and last sounds, omitting the middle vowel
Writing a letter name instead of the grapheme for the sound

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Spelling words with digraphs and adjacent consonants by segmenting and selecting appropriate graphemes.
levels.example_task: Spell the word 'black'. Say each sound first, then write the letters.
levels.example_response: Child says /b/ /l/ /a/ /ck/ and writes 'black'.
common_errors: Writing 'blak' — using 'k' instead of 'ck' after a short vowel
Omitting a letter from the consonant cluster: 'back' or 'blac'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Spelling age-appropriate words accurately by applying phonic knowledge, choosing correctly between alternative graphemes.
levels.example_task: Write this sentence from dictation: 'The train went through the dark tunnel.'
levels.example_response: Child writes the sentence with 'train' (ai), 'through' (exception), 'dark', 'tunnel' spelled correctly.
common_errors: Using a plausible alternative grapheme: 'trane' for 'train'
Spelling 'through' phonetically as 'throo'

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Spelling words with less common grapheme choices and explaining why a particular grapheme is used.
levels.example_task: Spell the word 'weight'. Which grapheme did you use for the /ay/ sound? Why not 'ai' or 'a-e'?
levels.example_response: Writes 'weight'. 'I used "eigh" for the /ay/ sound. It's not "ai" or "a-e" — "eigh" is a less common way to spell it. You just have to learn which words use "eigh".'
common_errors: Spelling 'wate' or 'wait' instead of 'weight'
Knowing the correct spelling but unable to explain why this grapheme is used

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading and beginning to spell a small set of the most common exception words (the, I, to, no, go).
levels.example_task: Look at the word 'said'. Cover it up. Now write it from memory.
levels.example_response: Child writes 'said' correctly.
common_errors: Writing 'sed' using phonics rules
Needing to look at the word multiple times before being able to write it

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Spelling most Year 1 exception words correctly using look-say-cover-write-check strategies.
levels.example_task: Spell these words without looking: 'was', 'you', 'they', 'are', 'were'.
levels.example_response: Child spells all five words correctly from memory.
common_errors: Spelling 'wos' for 'was' or 'thay' for 'they'
Confusing 'were' and 'where'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Spelling Year 1 and Year 2 exception words correctly in independent writing, not just in spelling tests.
levels.example_task: Write a sentence about your weekend. Use at least two exception words correctly.
levels.example_response: 'On Saturday I could not find my favourite shoes because they were behind the door.' (Exception words: could, find, favourite, because, behind used correctly.)
common_errors: Spelling exception words correctly in tests but reverting to phonetic spellings in free writing
Spelling some exception words correctly but not others

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Spelling exception words accurately and consistently, and identifying which part of each word is 'tricky'.
levels.example_task: Circle the tricky part of each word: 'beautiful', 'because', 'Christmas', 'different'. Explain what makes each part tricky.
levels.example_response: 'Beautiful — the "eau" makes an /oo/ sound, which is unusual. Because — the "au" makes an /o/ sound. Christmas — the "Ch" makes a /k/ sound. Different — the second "e" is easy to forget because you can't hear it.'
common_errors: Circling the whole word as tricky instead of the specific irregular part
Not recognising that some parts of exception words follow regular patterns

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding -s to regular nouns and verbs to make plurals or third person forms.
levels.example_task: Make these words plural by adding -s: 'cat', 'dog', 'cup'.
levels.example_response: Cats, dogs, cups.
common_errors: Forgetting to add -s at all
Adding -s but pronouncing it incorrectly

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Adding common suffixes (-s, -es, -ing, -ed, -er, -est) to words without spelling changes.
levels.example_task: Add the suffix to each word: 'jump + ing', 'tall + er', 'box + es'.
levels.example_response: Jumping, taller, boxes.
common_errors: Adding -s instead of -es to words ending in x, sh, ch (e.g., 'boxs')
Forgetting to use -es when the word ends in a sibilant

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Applying suffix spelling rules including doubling consonants and dropping final 'e'.
levels.example_task: Add -ing to these words: 'hope', 'run', 'play'.
levels.example_response: Hoping (drop the e), running (double the n), playing (just add -ing).
common_errors: Writing 'hopeing' instead of 'hoping' — not dropping the final 'e'
Writing 'runing' instead of 'running' — not doubling the consonant

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining suffix spelling rules and identifying the root word within a suffixed form.
levels.example_task: The word is 'happiest'. What is the root word? What suffix was added? What spelling rule was used?
levels.example_response: 'The root word is "happy". The suffix is "-est". The spelling rule is: when a word ends in a consonant + y, change the y to i before adding the suffix. So happy becomes happiest.'
common_errors: Identifying the suffix but not being able to state the spelling rule
Not recognising that the root word's spelling has changed

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Understanding that adding 'un-' to the start of a word changes its meaning to the opposite.
levels.example_task: What is the opposite of 'happy'? Add 'un' to the beginning.
levels.example_response: Unhappy.
common_errors: Not understanding what 'adding to the beginning' means
Saying 'not happy' instead of 'unhappy'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using 'un-' with a range of adjectives and verbs to create opposites.
levels.example_task: Add 'un-' to make the opposite: 'kind', 'lock', 'fair', 'do'.
levels.example_response: Unkind, unlock, unfair, undo.
common_errors: Trying to add 'un-' to words where it doesn't work (e.g., 'unbig')
Changing the spelling of the root word when adding the prefix

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using the prefix 'un-' correctly in own writing and recognising it in reading to work out word meanings.
levels.example_task: You find the word 'unbreakable' in your reading book. You haven't seen it before. What might it mean? How do you know?
levels.example_response: 'I can see "un" at the start which means "not", and "break" in the middle. So "unbreakable" means something that cannot be broken.'
common_errors: Not looking for the prefix as a strategy for working out unfamiliar words
Knowing 'un-' means 'not' but unable to apply it to a new word

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Distinguishing genuine prefixed words from words that simply begin with the letters 'un', and recognising that other prefixes exist.
levels.example_task: Which of these words actually have the prefix 'un-': 'unhappy', 'uncle', 'under', 'unfair', 'until'? How can you tell?
levels.example_response: 'Unhappy' and 'unfair' have the prefix 'un-' because if you take away 'un', you get a real word (happy, fair). 'Uncle', 'under' and 'until' don't have a prefix — they are just words that start with those letters.
common_errors: Thinking all words beginning with 'un' have the prefix
Not applying the test of removing 'un' to check if a root word remains

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying the base word when a simple suffix is added.
levels.example_task: What is the root word in 'jumping'?
levels.example_response: Jump.
common_errors: Saying 'jumpi' — not identifying the correct suffix boundary
Not understanding what 'root word' means

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying root words in words with common suffixes and the prefix 'un-'.
levels.example_task: Find the root word in each: 'unhappy', 'played', 'tallest', 'careful'.
levels.example_response: Happy, play, tall, care.
common_errors: Removing too many letters (e.g., saying the root of 'careful' is 'car')
Not recognising that the root word can change spelling when suffixes are added

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using knowledge of root words to read and spell new words in the same word family.
levels.example_task: If you know the word 'help', what other words can you make? Try adding different suffixes and the prefix 'un-'.
levels.example_response: Helps, helped, helping, helper, helpful, unhelpful, helpless.
common_errors: Creating words that don't exist (e.g., 'helply')
Only producing one or two variations instead of exploring the full word family

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining how root words carry meaning through a word family and using this to decode unfamiliar words in reading.
levels.example_task: You see the word 'mistreatment' in a book. You know the word 'treat'. How does that help you work out what 'mistreatment' means?
levels.example_response: 'I know "treat" means how you act towards someone. "Mis" at the start means badly or wrongly. "Ment" at the end makes it a noun. So "mistreatment" means treating someone badly.'
common_errors: Identifying the root word but not using the prefix and suffix to build the full meaning
Knowing what 'treat' means but not connecting it to the longer word

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Making regular nouns plural by adding -s.
levels.example_task: I have one cat. Now I have two... Write the word.
levels.example_response: Cats.
common_errors: Writing 'cat' without the -s
Adding -es when only -s is needed

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applying -s and -es rules correctly, knowing that -es follows words ending in s, sh, ch, x, z.
levels.example_task: Make these words plural: 'bus', 'fox', 'church', 'hat'.
levels.example_response: Buses, foxes, churches, hats.
common_errors: Writing 'buss' or 'foxs' — not applying the -es rule
Adding -es to all words regardless of ending

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Forming plurals correctly including changing -y to -ies and recognising common irregular plurals.
levels.example_task: Write the plural of: 'baby', 'city', 'child', 'tooth', 'day'.
levels.example_response: Babies, cities, children, teeth, days.
common_errors: Writing 'babys' instead of 'babies' — not changing y to i
Writing 'childs' instead of 'children' — not knowing the irregular form

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining plural formation rules and handling unusual cases including words that do not change in the plural.
levels.example_task: Why is the plural of 'baby' spelled 'babies' but the plural of 'day' is 'days'? What is the rule?
levels.example_response: 'When a word ends in a consonant + y (like baby: b is a consonant before y), you change y to i and add -es. When a word ends in a vowel + y (like day: a is a vowel before y), you just add -s.'
common_errors: Stating the rule for one case but not the other
Not understanding the vowel/consonant distinction before the 'y'

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Understanding that a contraction is a shorter way of saying two words, with adult support.
levels.example_task: I say 'can not'. What is the short way of saying it? Listen: can't.
levels.example_response: Can't.
common_errors: Not understanding the concept of combining two words into one
Saying 'cannot' as one word but not recognising 'can't' as the contraction

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading and writing common contractions, placing the apostrophe in the correct position.
levels.example_task: Write the contraction for: 'do not', 'I am', 'it is', 'we will'.
levels.example_response: Don't, I'm, it's, we'll.
common_errors: Placing the apostrophe in the wrong position (e.g., 'do'nt')
Writing the contraction without an apostrophe (e.g., 'dont')

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using contractions accurately in own writing and explaining which letters the apostrophe replaces.
levels.example_task: Write the contraction for 'they are'. Where does the apostrophe go? Which letter does it replace?
levels.example_response: 'They're'. The apostrophe goes between the 'y' and 'r'. It replaces the letter 'a' from 'are'.
common_errors: Confusing 'they're' with 'their' or 'there'
Knowing the contraction but not being able to explain which letter is replaced

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Distinguishing between apostrophes for contraction and possession, and handling unusual contractions like 'won't'.
levels.example_task: The word 'won't' is a contraction. Which two words does it come from? Why is it unusual?
levels.example_response: 'Won't' comes from 'will not'. It's unusual because it doesn't look like you'd expect — it should be 'willn't' but instead the whole word changes to 'won't'. It's an irregular contraction.
common_errors: Thinking 'won't' comes from 'would not' instead of 'will not'
Not recognising that 'won't' is irregular

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Understanding that the apostrophe + s shows something belongs to someone, with physical objects as support.
levels.example_task: This is the hat that belongs to the girl. How do we write that? 'The girl___ hat.'
levels.example_response: The girl's hat.
common_errors: Writing 'the girls hat' without the apostrophe
Not understanding what 'belongs to' means in this context

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using apostrophe + s with singular nouns to show possession in simple sentences.
levels.example_task: Rewrite using a possessive apostrophe: 'The bone belongs to the dog.'
levels.example_response: The dog's bone.
common_errors: Writing 'the dogs bone' without the apostrophe
Placing the apostrophe after the s: 'the dogs' bone' (as if plural)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using possessive apostrophes with singular nouns accurately in own writing, distinguishing from plural -s.
levels.example_task: Write two sentences: one where 'dogs' is plural and one where 'dog's' is possessive.
levels.example_response: 'Three dogs played in the park.' (plural) 'The dog's tail wagged happily.' (possessive)
common_errors: Using the apostrophe for both plural and possessive
Omitting the apostrophe in possessive use during free writing

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the difference between plural -s, possessive 's, and contraction apostrophes clearly.
levels.example_task: Explain the difference between 'the cat's bowl', 'the cats ran away', and 'the cat's sleeping'. What does the apostrophe do in each?
levels.example_response: 'The cat's bowl' — the apostrophe shows the bowl belongs to the cat (possessive). 'The cats ran away' — no apostrophe, just plural, more than one cat. 'The cat's sleeping' — the apostrophe is a contraction of 'the cat is sleeping'.
common_errors: Confusing the possessive and contraction uses of 's
Explaining one use correctly but muddling the others

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising that some words sound the same but are spelled differently, with common pairs.
levels.example_task: Listen: 'see' and 'sea'. Do they sound the same? Do they mean the same thing?
levels.example_response: 'They sound the same but "see" means to look and "sea" means the water at the beach.'
common_errors: Thinking the words must mean the same thing because they sound the same
Not being able to explain the different meanings

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Choosing the correct homophone in a sentence for common pairs (to/too/two, here/hear, there/their).
levels.example_task: Choose the right word: 'I went ___ the shop.' (to/too/two)
levels.example_response: 'to' — 'I went to the shop.'
common_errors: Selecting 'too' or 'two' because they sound the same and the child hasn't learned the meaning distinction
Guessing randomly between the options

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Spelling common homophones correctly in own writing by considering meaning in context.
levels.example_task: Write three sentences, each using a different spelling: 'there', 'their', 'they're'.
levels.example_response: 'The book is over there.' 'Their dog is called Rex.' 'They're going to the park.'
common_errors: Using 'there' for all three meanings
Getting two correct but confusing the third

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the meaning difference between homophones and proof-reading own work to check homophones are correct.
levels.example_task: Proof-read this paragraph and correct any homophone errors: 'There going too the beach. I can here the waves. Its going to bee a lovely day.'
levels.example_response: 'They're going to the beach. I can hear the waves. It's going to be a lovely day.' Corrections: there→they're, too→to, here→hear, Its→It's, bee→be.
common_errors: Spotting some homophone errors but missing others
Correcting the homophone but introducing a new error

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Applying basic spelling patterns such as -ck after a short vowel in simple words.
levels.example_task: Spell these words: 'back', 'duck', 'neck'.
levels.example_response: Child writes 'back', 'duck', 'neck' with 'ck' correctly placed.
common_errors: Writing 'bak' or 'bac' — not using 'ck' after the short vowel
Using 'ck' in words where it doesn't belong (e.g., 'lick' correct but 'parck' incorrect)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applying KS1 spelling patterns including -tch, the /dʒ/ sound as 'ge'/'dge', and 'kn'/'gn' at word beginnings.
levels.example_task: Spell these words: 'catch', 'badge', 'know', 'gnaw'.
levels.example_response: Child spells all four words correctly.
common_errors: Writing 'cach' instead of 'catch' — missing the 't' in '-tch'
Writing 'naw' instead of 'gnaw' — not including the silent 'g'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Applying a range of spelling rules and patterns accurately in independent writing.
levels.example_task: Write a sentence using at least two words with different spelling patterns you have learned (e.g., silent letters, -dge, -tch).
levels.example_response: 'I knew the knight would catch the badge.' (kn-, -ight, -tch, -dge patterns)
common_errors: Applying rules in spelling tests but reverting to phonetic spelling in free writing
Using one pattern correctly but misspelling another pattern in the same sentence

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining spelling rules and identifying when a pattern does or does not apply.
levels.example_task: We use '-tch' in 'catch' but not in 'much'. When do we use '-tch' instead of '-ch'?
levels.example_response: 'We use "-tch" after a short vowel sound: catch, match, fetch, stitch. But some common words are exceptions: much, such, rich, which. After a consonant or long vowel, we just use "-ch": lunch, teach.'
common_errors: Stating the rule but not knowing the exceptions
Not understanding that the rule depends on the vowel sound before the ending
